text:
The athletes have done their final lap in the closing ceremonies, which means the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang are over.

But before we cast our eyes to Tokyo in 2020, here are the thing we’ll remember most from the Games in South Korea:

1. Chloe Kim’s incredible gold-medal run

2. Team USA’s Curling gold that’s straight out of Hollywood

After disastrous finishes at the last two Olympic Games, Team USA won its first-ever gold by stunning Sweden.

3. The U.S. women’s hockey team beating Canada to win gold, 20 years after Nagano ’98

4. Gus Kenworthy adopting a dog at the Olympics (again)

5. Adam Rippon’s dazzling free skate

Rippon helped Team USA take bronze in the team event.

Gerard wasn’t one of the favorites to win men’s slopestyle, but just like Sage Kotsenburg did four years ago in Sochi, Gerard stormed to the top of the podium with a stellar run.

8. Chris Mazdzer winning Team USA’s first-ever men’s singles luge medal

9. Ester Ledecka’s double gold

Ledecka, a world champion snowboarder, came to these Games without a single career top-10 finish on skis. She not only stunned the world by winning women’s super-G, but dominated parallel snowboard giant slalom to become the first athlete to win gold in skiing and snowboarding competitions at the same games.

And he didn’t finish last in cross country!

11. Unified Korea’s entrance to the 2018 Winter Games

14. The epic duel between Alina Zagitova and Evgenia Medvedeva

Zagitova, a 15-year-old, barely edged Medvedeva by just over a point to take gold in a competition for the ages.

16. Elizabeth Swaney living out Olympic dreams thanks to loopholes

Take that, haters.

Along with the incredible call of Kikkan Randall and Jessie Diggins winning gold.

19. Yuzuru Hanyu repeating as men’s figure skating gold medalist for the first time since Dick Button

20. South Korea’s Iron Man wins gold

23-year-old Yung Sungbin build up a big enough lead in men’s skeleton that his final run was essentially a victory lap, and the home crowd went nuts for him.

21. Chloe Kim establishing herself as the greatest Olympic Twitterer

22. Mark McMorris’ inspiring comeback

McMorris suffered near-fatal injuries last March after hitting a tree in the backcountry of British Columbia and needed two surgeries after suffering a fractured jaw, a fractured left arm, a ruptured spleen, a pelvic fracture, rib fractures and a collapsed left lung. Less than a year later, he was back on the Olympic stage, and he left Pyeongchang with a bronze medal.

23. Two-man bobsled ends in a gold-medal tie.

Germany and Canada split the golds after the two countries put up the exact same time down to the hundredth of a second.
authors: Charles Is A Writer For For The Win. He Once Dropped An Easy Foul Ball At Shea Stadium
title: The 23 best moments from the 2018 Winter Olympics

meta_data.description: The most memorable moments from the Winter Games.
